facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 290 and 291 of 1961 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 290 291 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated September 25, 1957, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in writ Petitions No. 1172 of 1956 and 56 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated September 25, 1957, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court, in writ Petitions No. 1172 of 1956 of 1957.

facts.text: Petitions Nos. 1172 of 1956 and 56 of 1957 filed under Art. 226 of the Constitution questioning the validity of the Andhra Act XIV of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: in petitions Nos. 11 72 of 1956 and 56 of 1957 filed under Art. 226 of the Constitution questioning the validity of the Andhra Act XIV of 1955 insofar as it imposes a tax on the sale of Virginia tobacco.

facts.text: Appellants are firms doing business in the export of tobacco.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are firms doing business in the export of tobacco.

facts.text: Usual course of business: enter into contracts with customers abroad for sale of tobacco, purchase requisite quantities locally, export to foreign purchasers.

anchor.surface_text: The usual course of that business is stated to be that they first enter into contracts with their customers abroad for the sale of tobacco, that thereafter they purchase the requisite quantities of goods locally and then export them to the foreign purchasers in performance of their contracts.

facts.text: Prior to October 1, 1953, the area wherein appellants carried on business formed part of the State of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to October 1, 1953, the area wherein the appellants carried on business formed part of the State of Madras, and on that date the- State of Andhra was constituted,

facts.text: On October 1, 1953, State of Andhra was constituted and the area fell within that State.

anchor.surface_text: and on that date the- State of Andhra was constituted, and the area in question fell within that State.

facts.text: Madras General Sales Tax Act, IX of 1939 was in force in that area.

anchor.surface_text: The law relating to sales tax in force in that area it the Madras General Sales Tax Act, TX of 1939.

facts.text: Government of Madras issued notification No. 144 on March 31, 1953, exempting sales of unmanufactured tobacco from sales tax.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers conferred by s. 6 the Government of Madras issued on March 31, 1953, a notification No. 144 exempting the sales of unmanufactured tobacco from sales tax.

facts.text: Andhra Legislature enacted Act XIV of 1955 amending s. 5 of Madras General Sales Tax Act by adding item viii taxing raw tobacco except country variety at 7.5 pies per rupee on first purchase.

anchor.surface_text: After the Andhra State came into existence, the Legislature of that State enacted Act XIV of 1955 hereinafter referred to as the Amendment Act whereby it amended s. 5 of the Madras General Sales Tax Act by adding as item  viii  the following - raw tobacco  except country variety thereof whether cured or uncured, shall be liable to tax under Section 3, Sub Section 1 only at the point of the first purchase effected in the State of Andhra by a dealer who is not exempt from taxation under Section 3, Sub Section 3 but at the rate of seven and half pies for every rupee on his turnover.

facts.text: Explanation in Act: country variety of tobacco means variety other than Virginia and other similar varieties.

anchor.surface_text: Explanation -For the purpose of this item, country variety of tobacco means variety of tobacco other than Virginia and other similar varieties of tobacco.

facts.text: Result of enactment: exemption limited to country tobacco (Nattu tobacco), Virginia tobacco sales became liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of this enactment exemption from tax was limited to sales of what is known as country tobacco  Nattu tobacco  and so far as sales of Virginia tobacco are concerned, they became liable to be taxed.

facts.text: Andhra Government issued notification No. 711 on November 4, 1955, cancelling earlier notification No. 144.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the Amendment Act, the Andhra Government issued on November 4, 1955, a notification No. 711 cancelling the earlier notification No. 144 dated March 31, 1953.

facts.text: Additional Commercial Tax Officer, Guntur, issued notices to appellants to produce account books for assessing sales tax.

anchor.surface_text: Acting under the provisions of the Amendment Act, the Additional Commercial Tax Officer, Guntur, issued notices to the appellants to produce the account books relating to their business in tobacco for the purpose of assessing sales tax.

facts.text: Appellants filed writ petitions challenging constitutionality of Amendment Act as discriminatory under Art. 14 and contravening Art. 286(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: To this the appellants replied by filing petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Andhra Pradesh challenging the constitutionality of the Amendment Act on the grounds inter alia that in taxing sales of Virginia tobacco and exempting from tax sales of other tobacco, the Act was discriminatory, and that in consequence it was obnoxious to Art. 14 of the Constitution and that further it was in contravention of Art. 286  1   b  as it was really a tax on sales in the course of export of tobacco.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the petitions holding the Act does not infringe constitutional provisions, granted certificates under Art. 133.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges disagreed with these contentions and dismissed the petitions, holding that the impugned Act did not infringe any constitutional provisions, but granted certificates under Art. 133 of the Constitution.

facts.text: There are two types of tobacco: Virginia and Nattu, differing in taste, flavour, texture, nomenclature, process of growing, curing, grading, market facilities, price, uses, customers.

anchor.surface_text: Broadly, there are two types,Virginia and Nattu, differing in taste, light, flavour and texture There are obvious  1  1961 2 S C. R. 77, differences between the two categories of to- bacco, in the nomenclature used, in the process of growing, curing and grading, in the market facilities foreign and inland, in the price and in the variety of uses to which they are put and also the class of customers that take to them.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds differences between Virginia and Nattu tobacco justify treating Virginia as a class for taxation.

anchor.surface_text: Thus it will be seen that Virginia tobacco has features which distinguish it from country tobacco, and can be treated as a class in itself. It will therefore be within the power of the State to impose a tax on the sales of Virginia tobacco while exempting the country tobacco.

facts.text: Purchases by appellants were made for purpose of executing specific orders from foreign customers.

anchor.surface_text: It may be assumed for the purpose of the present discussion that the purchases made by the appellants on which the tax is sought to be imposed were made for the purpose of executing specific orders which they had received from their foreign customers.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds the tax is not on sales in course of export under Art. 286(1)(b), as it is on purchases preceding the export sale.

anchor.surface_text: On these authorities the law must be taken to be well settled that it is only the sale under which the export is made that is protected by Art 286  1  b , and that a purchase which precedes such a sale does not fall within its purview though it is made for the purpose of, or with a view to export.

facts.text: High Court judgment delivered on September 25, 1957.
